across.text: Vessel has slate on lip
across.explanation: SAUCEPAN(i.e. “vessel”). Solution is SAUCE (i.e. “lip”) then PAN (i.e. to “slate” something).

across.text: Settle down in Arsenal’s opening match
across.explanation: ALIGHT(i.e. “settle down”). Solution is A (i.e. “Arsenal’s opening”, i.e. the first letter of “Arsenal”) followed by LIGHT (i.e. “match”).

across.text: Calm down, please: official’s inside
across.explanation: EASE OFF(i.e. “calm down”). “Inside” suggests the solution is hidden in the clue, like so: PL(EASE OFF)ICIAL.

across.text: Modish poem contains a line on worker, perhaps without style
across.explanation: INELEGANTLY(i.e. “without style”). Solution is IN (i.e. popular, trendy or “modish”) followed by ELEGY (i.e. “poem”) “containing” ANT (i.e. “worker”) and L (a recognised abbreviation of “line”), like so: IN-ELEG(ANT-L)Y.

across.text: Doctor knocked back drink, once again dispatched everywhere
across.explanation: OMNIPRESENT(i.e. “everywhere”). Solution is OM (i.e. “doctor knocked back”, i.e. the initial letters of Medical Officer reversed) followed by NIP (i.e. “drink”) and RESENT (i.e. “once again dispatched”).

across.text: Confidence bound to be picked up
across.explanation: TRUST(i.e. “confidence”). “To be picked up” suggests the solution is a homophone of “trussed” (i.e. “bound”).

across.text: Clouds having been formed containing radioactive element, note
across.explanation: NEBULAE(i.e. “clouds”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “formed”) of BEEN “containing” U (i.e. “radioactive element”, specifically the chemical symbol for uranium) and LA (i.e. “note”, as in the do-ray-me scale), like so: NEB(U-LA)E.

across.text: Novel with fantastic genre to flog in bulletin
across.explanation: NEWSFLASH(i.e. “bulletin”). Solution is NEW (i.e. “novel”) followed by SF (i.e. “fantastic genre”, specifically Science Fiction) and LASH (i.e. “to flog”).

across.text: Abnormal sort of water in Derwent’s banks
across.explanation: DEVIANT(i.e. “abnormal”). Solution is EVIAN (i.e. “sort of water”) placed “in” DT (i.e. “Derwent’s banks”, i.e. the first and last letters of “Derwent”), like so: D(EVIAN)T.

across.text: Send on deployment of troops, say, following Thirty Years War?
across.explanation: POST-REFORMATION(i.e. “following Thirty Years War”). Solution is POST (i.e. “send”) followed by RE (i.e. “on”, as in “regarding”) and FORMATION (i.e. “deployment of troops”).

across.text: Used to give support, at first
across.explanation: SECOND-HAND(i.e. “used”).I’m a little wobbly on this. I get that SECOND is “to give support”, and you might perhaps do so by raising your hand, but to be honest I’m not quite tuned into what the setter’s doing here. I doubt I’ll miss any sleep over it.

across.text: Depict resistance fighters on edge, retreating
across.explanation: MIRROR(i.e. “depict”). Solution is R (a recognised abbreviation for electrical “resistance”) followed by OR (i.e. “fighters”, specifically the Other Ranks of the army) and RIM (i.e. “edge”) all reversed (i.e. “retreating”), like so: MIR-RO-R.

across.text: Condescend to listen to EU citizen
across.explanation: DANE(i.e. “EU citizen”). “To listen” suggests the solution is a homophone of “deign” (i.e. “condescend”).

across.text: Crazy whirl upstaging enchanting event?
across.explanation: WALPURGIS NIGHT, the night in German folklore when witches get down with the devil (i.e. “enchanting event”). “Crazy” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of WHIRL UPSTAGING.

across.text: A lot of craft to satisfy a welcoming crowd
across.explanation: FLOTILLA(i.e. “a lot of [sea]craft”). This one’s a mess, but I think the solution is LOT being “welcomed” into FILL (i.e. “to satisfy”) and A like so: F(LOT)ILL-A. Not a classic clue by any means.

across.text: Venomous man, a day tripper
across.explanation: ACIDHEAD(i.e. “tripper”). Solution is ACID (i.e. “venomous”) followed by HE (i.e. “man”) then A and D (a recognised abbreviation of “day”).

across.text: Hinder false advertiser, one offering advice
across.explanation: BACK-SEAT DRIVER(i.e. “one offering advice”). Solution is BACK (i.e. to “hinder” or hold back) followed by an anagram (indicated by “false”) of “advertiser”.

across.text: Make unclear, short publicity text
across.explanation: BLUR(i.e. “make unclear”. Solution is BLURB (i.e. “publicity text”) with the last letter removed (i.e. made “short”).

across.text: Heartless fool screening film in old age
across.explanation: NINETY(i.e. “in old age”). Solution is NINNY (i.e. “fool”) with the middle letter removed (i.e. “heartless”) and wrapped around (i.e. “screening”) ET (i.e. “film”), like so: NIN(ET)Y.

across.text: Admitting depression, crooks joining church recover
across.explanation: CONVALESCE(i.e. “recover”). Solution is CONS (i.e. “crooks”) “admitting” VALE (i.e. “depression”) and then followed by CE (i.e. “church”, specifically the Church of England), like so: CON(VALE)S-CE.

across.text: Subject promises to settle coastal area, being quarrelsome
across.explanation: CONTENTIOUSNESS(i.e. “quarrelsome”). Solution is CONTENT (i.e. “subject”) followed by IOUS (i.e. “promises to settle”) and NESS (which is another word for headland, i.e. “coastal area”).

across.text: Vain Englishman and American crossing river
across.explanation: POMPOUS(i.e. “vain”). Solution is POM (i.e. “Englishman”) and US (i.e. “American”) placed around, or “crossing”, PO (i.e. a “river” in Italy), like so: POM-(PO)-US.

across.text: Mobile phone with charm and a reluctance to innovate
across.explanation: NEOPHOBIA, a fear of new things (i.e. “reluctance to innovate”). Solution is NEOPH, an anagram (indicated by “mobile”) of “phone”, followed by OBI (a kind of “charm”) and A.

across.text: Agreement to embrace John? Nothing is impossible
across.explanation: NO CAN DO(i.e. “impossible”). Solution is NOD (i.e. “agreement”) “embracing” CAN (i.e. “John”, as in a toilet) and followed by O (i.e. “nothing”), like so: NO(CAN)D-O.

across.text: Crustacean luckily protecting back bones
across.explanation: ULNAE(i.e. “bones”). “Protecting” suggests the solution is hidden in the clue, and “back” suggests the clue is hidden backwards, like so: CRUSTAC(EAN LU)CKILY.

across.text: It’s almost the end in sentence
across.explanation: HOME STRETCH(i.e. “it’s almost the end”). Solution is HOME (i.e. “in”) and STRETCH (i.e. a prison “sentence”).

across.text: The writer’s to offer books without forethought
across.explanation: IMPROVIDENT(i.e. “without forethought”). Solution is IM (i.e. “the writer’s” – from the setter’s point of view “the writer is” becomes “I am”, which is contracted to I’M) followed by PROVIDE (i.e. “to offer”) and NT (i.e. “books”, specifically the New Testament).

across.text: Singular art including most blue
across.explanation: SADDEST(i.e. “most blue”). Solution is S (a recognised abbreviation of “singular”). The rest of the clue will take some explaining. “Art including” should be read as ye olde “[Someone] art including [something]”, i.e. read as “is including”. To include something is to “add” it. Keeping it all ye olde, “art including” therefore becomes something like “Lucian ADDEST another reader to his blog”. So, the solution is S-ADDEST. I like and despise this clue in equal measure.

across.text: Person managing to seize one unoriginal type
across.explanation: COPIER(i.e. “unoriginal type”). Solution is COPER (i.e. “person managing”) “seizing” I (Roman numeral “one”), like so: COP(I)ER.

across.text: Kid by cool water experiencing heat
across.explanation: IN SEASON(i.e. “experiencing heat”). Solution is SON (i.e. “kid”) placed “by” IN (i.e. “cool”) and SEA (i.e. “water”), like so: IN-SEA-SON.

down.text: Awkward son went off the straight and narrow
down.explanation: STILTED(i.e. “awkward”). Solution is S (a recognised abbreviation of “son”) followed by TILTED (i.e. “went off the straight and narrow”).

down.text: A French ass, say, mostly loud and clear
down.explanation: UNEQUIVOCAL(i.e. “clear”). Solution is UN (i.e. “a French”, as in the French for “a”) followed by EQUI (i.e. “ass, say, mostly”, i.e. the word “equid” – which describes horses, zebras and asses – with the final letter removed) and VOCAL (i.e. “loud”).

down.text: Reader’s issue with English agreed by school
down.explanation: EYESTRAIN(i.e. “reader’s issue”). Solution is E (a recognised abbreviation of “English”) followed by YES (i.e. “agreed”) and TRAIN (i.e. to “school” someone).

down.text: Unnatural profit, in a way, with vodka and beer
down.explanation: AGAINST THE GRAIN(i.e. “unnatural”). Solution is A GAIN (i.e. “profit”) followed by ST (i.e. “a way”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “street”) and THE GRAIN (i.e. “vodka and beer” I guess).

down.text: No republican initially changing sides? He won’t
down.explanation: LOYALIST. Solution is ROYALIST (i.e. “no republican”) with the first letter R (a recognised abbreviation of “right”) switched for L (ditto “left”) i.e. “initially changing sides”. In the context of the clue, a loyalist is someone who won’t change sides.

down.text: Blooming head of theatre and choir take off
down.explanation: GLOBE ARTICHOKE(i.e. “blossoming head”). Solution is GLOBE (i.e. the famous Shakespearean “theatre” in London) followed by an anagram (indicated by “off”) of CHOIR TAKE.

down.text: It helps musician to grin, with funk playing
down.explanation: TUNING FORK(i.e. “it helps musician”). “Playing” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of TO GRIN and FUNK.

down.text: Entitle army corps to pull back holding detainee
down.explanation: EMPOWER(i.e. “entitle”). Solution is REME (i.e. “army corps”, specifically the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers) reversed (i.e. “pulled back”) and then “holding” POW (i.e. “detainee”), like so: EM(POW)ER.

down.text: Note what’s up in the papers?
down.explanation: SHEAF(i.e. “papers”). Solution is FA (i.e. “note”, as in the do-ray-me scale) and EHS (i.e. “what’s”, as in “eh, what was that?”) all reversed (indicated by “up” – this being a down clue), like so: SHE-AF.

down.text: Frank, mostly sensible, is running
down.explanation: OPERATIONAL(i.e. “is running”). Solution is OPE (i.e. “frank, mostly”, i.e. the word “open” with the last letter removed) followed by RATIONAL (i.e. “sensible”).

down.text: Pretty female making an impression
down.explanation: FETCHING(i.e. “pretty”). Solution is F (a recognised abbreviation of “female” followed by ETCHING (i.e. “making an impression”).

down.text: Go crazy, in a spin
down.explanation: STAB(as in to have an attempt, or a “go”, at something). Solution is BATS (i.e. “crazy”) reversed (i.e. “in a spin”).

down.text: Castigate attempt at humour, to a degree
down.explanation: PUNISH. Solution satisfies “castigate” and “attempt at humour, to a degree” i.e. not quite a pun.

down.text: Go off northwards after car, I hear
down.explanation: AUDITOR(i.e. “I hear”, as opposed to the ever-increasing number of firms found to be skilled at overlooking corporate financial mismanagement and white-collar crime). Solution is ROT (i.e. “go off”) reversed (indicated by “northwards” – this being a down clue) and placed after AUDI (i.e. “car”) like so: AUDI-TOR.

down.text: I’m not interested in female item of clothing
down.explanation: SO WHAT(i.e. “I’m not interested”). Solution is SOW (i.e. “female”) and HAT (i.e. “item of clothing”).

down.text: Maybe what could make inventor pour ale
down.explanation: RELATIVE PRONOUN, which, I guess, is the word “what” in the clue (i.e. “Maybe what”). “Could make” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of INVENTOR POUR ALE.

down.text: Inclusive approach gets old man aboard Britain’s new vessel
down.explanation: BIPARTISANSHIP(i.e. “inclusive approach”). Solution is PA (i.e. “old man”) placed “aboard” an anagram (indicated by “new”) of BRITAINS and followed by SHIP (i.e. “vessel”), like so: BI(PA)RTISAN-SHIP.

down.text: Children’s writer’s block has no end
down.explanation: [J. M.]BARRIE, author ofPeter Pan(i.e. “children’s writer”). Solution is BARRIER (i.e. “block”) with “no end”, i.e. the last letter removed.

down.text: Throw up, at first, on new drug
down.explanation: UNHORSE(i.e. “throw”). Solution is U (i.e. “up, at first”, i.e. the first letter of the word “up”) followed by N (a recognised abbreviation of “new”) and HORSE (i.e. “drug”, specifically a slang word for heroin).

down.text: Goddess, we’re told, is like a carrier of blood
down.explanation: VENOUS. Solution satisfies both “goddess, we’re told” – i.e. a homophone of “Venus” – and “like a carrier of blood”. Think of intravenous drips in hospitals.

down.text: One learner guided around in class is ignorant
down.explanation: ILL-INFORMED(i.e. “ignorant”). Solution is I (i.e. Roman numeral “one”) then L (a recognised abbreviation of “learner”) and LED (i.e. “guided”) placed “around” IN FORM (i.e. “in class”), like so: I-L-L(IN-FORM)ED.

down.text: Loveless letters penned by thick aristocrat
down.explanation: VISCOUNTESS(i.e. “aristocrat”). Solution is NOTES (i.e. “letters”) with the O removed (i.e. “loveless” – “love” being a zero score in tennis) and placed in VISCOUS (i.e. “thick”), like so: VISCOU(NTES)S.

down.text: Pragmatic criminal in court takes fellow in
down.explanation: UNROMANTIC(i.e. “pragmatic”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “criminal”) of IN COURT “taking in” MAN (i.e. “fellow”), like so: UNRO(MAN)TIC.

down.text: Echo behind cattle car
down.explanation: LIMOUSINE(i.e. “car”). Solution is E (“echo” in the phonetic alphabet) placed “behind” LIMOUSIN (a breed of “cattle”), like so: LIMOUSIN-E.

down.text: Kind of leaves a prison in this way
down.explanation: ACANTHUS(i.e. “kind of leaves”). Solution is A CAN (i.e. “a prison”) followed by THUS (i.e. “in this way”).

down.text: Responding with original, moving chapter
down.explanation: REACTIVE(i.e. “responding”). Solution is CREATIVE (i.e. “original”) with C moved down a couple of notches (i.e. “moving chapter” – C being a recognised abbreviation of “chapter”).

down.text: Not dressed in rubbish fabric
down.explanation: TABARET(i.e. “fabric”). Solution is BARE (i.e. “not dressed”) placed “in” TAT (i.e. “rubbish”), like so: TA(BARE)T. I admit I got this one purely by the wordplay.

down.text: Two versions of small figure to placate
down.explanation: SWEETEN(i.e. “to placate”). Solution is S (a recognised abbreviation of “small” used in clothing) and WEE (giving us “two versions of small”) followed by TEN (i.e. “figure”).

down.text: Eats meal briefly, in rush
down.explanation: HASTE(i.e. “in rush”). Solution is HAS TEA (i.e. “eats”) with the final letter removed from “tea” (indicated by “briefly”).

down.text: Regularly in toupee? You must be joking
down.explanation: NOPE(i.e. “you must be joking”). “Regularly” suggests the solution is derived by taking every other letter ofINTOUPEE.
